awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Evolutionary Significance of Biotic Interactions: A Comparative Study utilizing Echinoid Associated Traces
awd_abstract_narration:
Predators often leave distinct marks on prey skeletons, including tooth marks, fractures, scars, and drill holes. Fossils that contain those distinct marks can be used to explore the role of predation over the span of millions of years. To date, research on the fossil record of predation has centered mainly on mollusks: snails, clams, and their relatives. The proposed project will expand the history of predation beyond mollusks, and assess the impact of predation on sea urchins, sand dollars, and other echinoids. Echinoids are a commercially important group of animals and a major food source for many marine predators. This project aims to develop a global reference system for identifying traces left by predators on echinoid prey, which is expected to stimulate echinoid research on both modern and ancient ecosystems. Once assembled, the database will then be used to study the impact of predators on the evolution of echinoids over the last 100 million years, during which, they have diversified and become a critical part of the marine biosphere.

Neontological museum collections in conjunction with the literature will be used to codify trace characteristics of various types of interactions (predation, parasitism, commensalism, etc.) that affect modern echinoids. The resultant database will include data on the identity/ecology of trace makers, identity/ecology/phylogeny of affected echinoids, and morphology, frequency, and distribution of traces. The database will then be used to explore the fossil record, and evaluate hypotheses regarding the relative evolutionary importance of select types of biotic interactions affecting the ecology and evolutionary history of echinoids.
Results will be publicly available through museum activities, activity kits for middle school students, and teaching tools in the Florida Museum of Natural History Educator Resource program.

por.por_cntn:
In marine ecosystems, echinoids (sand dollars, sea biscuits, and other sea urchins) play an important role as hosts for parasites and as a food source for diverse predators, including crabs, snails, and vertebrates. These parasites and predators can leave unique traces on the skeletal remains of echinoids, making it possible to reconstruct predator-prey and parasite-host interactions in the fossil record. The ecological importance of echinoids in modern oceans and their abundant presence in the fossil record make them excellent model organisms for studying the evolutionary history of predator-prey and parasite-host interactions. The objective of the Echinoid Associated Traces (EAT) Project was to explore and document these ecological relationships.

The EAT Project focused on echinoid-parasite and echinoid-predator interactions preserved in the post-Paleozoic (approximately 250 million years and younger) fossil record of marine ecosystems. The primary aim was to quantify ecological interactions that may have influenced the evolution, ecology, and behavior of echinoids as well as their predators and parasites. To accomplish this we first identified modern predators and parasites that affect echinoids, and then described the shapes of the traces that resulted from their interactions. These descriptions were the basis for identifying and interpreting traces of ecological interactions preserved on fossil echinoids. Field work was conducted at fossil localities in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, and Mississippi. Two field trips to the Bahamas were conducted to study the unique predator-echinoid systems there. Another two sampling trips were done in the Gulf of Mexico. The scientific analyses we conducted were based on these recent and fossil specimens collected in the field, or retrieved from museum collections and scientific literature. The specimens came from nearly every continent and most geological epochs of the past 250 million years.

The major scientific goals and objectives of this project were to: 1) Explore trends in the evolution and escalation of predatory and parasitic behaviors by certain predatory snails on echinoids by studying drill-hole traces on Triassic to modern echinoids (findings suggest an escalation of echinoid-associated predatory and parasitic drilling over time, particularly during the mesozoic), 2) develop a database for the purposes of analyzing, archiving, and distributing paleontological and modern data on echinoid-associated drill holes. This dataset is publicly accessible both through a data repository (Dryad) and the interactive catalogue on the EAT project’s website www.eat-project.org, and 3) establish diagnostic criteria for fossil traces by examining modern echinoid-associated biotic interaction. These three goals were accomplished, and the data and results are available to the public or summarized in peer-reviewed scientific publications and disseminated through scientific presentations at professional conferences and educational talks.

The broader impacts to society accomplished by the EAT project included the following: 1) Training of undergraduate students, volunteers, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers in scientific data collection, protocol development and museum specimen curation, 2) development of educational material and data archives for future use by researchers and educators, and 3) contribution of more than 16 thousand new curated specimens to the Florida Museum Invertebrate Paleontology collections (the data for these specimens are available online through the museum’s searchable databases).

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Carrie Tyler
